This is a gorgeous Victorian near Alamo Square that just popped out on an Expedia search. It's an amazing looking, ornate house on Steiner Street just steps from the Painted Ladies and a short walk to the San Francisco City Hall/Asian Art Museum area. The nearest BART stop is Civic Center which is about a mile away, so could be considered a bit of a hike for some. We usually didn't find this to be a problem.We stayed in the Joaquin Miller room, which is one of the smaller rooms on the third floor. The bed in there was only a double or full so we were a bit cozy but it was otherwise very comfortable. Some rooms have a private bathroom but ours was shared, which was a (very) slight inconvenience, but also one we were aware up when we booked. The claw-foot tub is cool looking but takes a little maneuvering to not get water on the floor. We did some laundry in the bathtub and hung it up to dry in the room.During the week they provide a continental breakfast buffet (coffee/tea, assorted bread and jam, meat, and cheese). On the weekend they'll cook you a hot breakfast from 9-11, which was quite delicious. Once day was French toast with fresh fruit and the other was quiche and a salad. The option of champagne/orange juice/mimosas was also provided with the hot breakfast. They also provide wine and cheese in the parlor from 4-6 every day. We usually missed this since we were out but it was a welcome treat the day we arrived.I was unable to get a decent WiFi signal in my room to save my life (tried all 3 available networks), however my wife didn't have this problem and she was right next to me, so it may have been a problem with my computer that I was just too lazy to solve at the time.Overall, a really cool place and we'd love to stay here again, and maybe check out of the bigger rooms.

Actually we have stayed here - near Alamo Square and the Painted Lady Victorians - 4 or 5 times whilst visiting one of our children. Like a home away from home. Funky-exquisite decor; you can imagine the bohemian lifestyle once led by its "real" occupants. Totally private. No one bugs you. Afternoon wine and cheese is set out in the Victorian parlor. Oh and did I mention the tasty no-fuss breakfasts. Even after 4 visits we have much to learn about just this one beautiful SF landmark hotel.

What a brilliant little place this is. It's so beautifully restored to Victorian standards, it was like going back in time.We were warmly welcomed by Nicholas, who throughout our stay helped us on numerous occasions. Can't thank him enough for going over and above his duties. Great guy.Bridget and the other staff were always polite and helpful, just what you want when you're away from home.No bar here but at 16:00 - 18:00 they brought out wine, cheese and biscuits. After a long and tiring day touring SF it was lovely just to relax and meet other guests, have a chat and find out the best places to visit - it was a lovely touch.5 Minutes walk from the 'Painted Ladies' and easy access to local buses but Nicholas put an app on my phone for a cab company called Lyft who were very efficient and reasonably priced.Highly recommend this lovely little 'Painted lady'.

End of a three week trip splurge. It was worth it. We took tge bourgeois Tetrazini suite for three days and it was great. Bed was a little bendy in rhe middle but everything else was fabulous. I loved the peace and quiet. No television. Breakfast was good. One of the mornings there was fresh baked quiche which was awesome. Coffee was nice and really helpful staff. Great to chat with and helpful to ask traveller style questions. Its a great place to stay if you just eant to bunker down too. Very pleasant. Artful and elegant.

Champagne Breakfast, wonderful suite, great location.The staff was so wonderful. We hated to leave the room.The wine and cheese was delicious at happy hour. The common area and our room was decorated in some beautiful antiques. We stayed in a tower suite so we had nice bay windows.

We stayed in the two basement suites - Lola Montez and Lily Langtry. The suites were beautifully decorated, clean and very spacious. The building itself is amazing and if you are looking for a boutique hotel that is also quirky and in an excellent location then look no further. Close to excellent bus links and within easy walking distance of many local attractions it is a bonus to be outside of the busy Union Square district. The hosts were welcoming, very helpful and generous with their time and gave us plenty of information. Staying at the Chateau was like having the luxury of a hotel but also the freedom of being in your own home - being able to sit in the parlour and read, have a glass of wine or even order a takeaway! We loved it, we were all so sad to leave and say goodbye to such an incredible painted lady.

We had a marvelous stay at the Chateau Tivoli Bed & Breakfast. We were in the basement suite, which has two bedrooms, one bath and a private entrance. It was quiet and perfect for the three adults visiting the city for five nights. The hosts couldn't have been nicer and were very helpful with restaurant suggestions and transportation (very easy walk to public transportation). The breakfasts were excellent, as was the wine and cheese reception each evening. In an expensive city like San Francisco, it the Chateau Tivoli is an exceptional value as well. Highly recommended - we will be back!

I've been staying at the Chateau Tivoli for 12 years. As a music and movie lover I find it perfectly situated to easily get to multiple venues and theaters. With no two night minimum like many BnBs I generally come in just for the night of a show. It's just blocks from the Independent and the historic Fillmore auditorium. A quick bus or taxi ride gets you to the Opera, the Rickshaw Stop, the Regency or Warfield. Really, this neighborhood couldn't be more centrally located. Staying at the Tivoli and strolling to Divisadero street or Hayes valley feels like staying in a lively European town. There's an abundance of excellent restaurants on Divisadero street and there seems to be several new ones every time I visit. During my last visit around the holidays I found an excellent new greek place and a new ice cream shop!I've stayed in many of the rooms at the Tivoli and find that they each have a unique and distinct charm. I splurged on the Mark Twain Suite once and have to say that would be my favorite but I most often prefer to stay in the Isadora Duncan room. Even though the bathroom is across the hall, it is private and huge! It has what looks to be the original tile and a claw foot tub. The room itself is very comfortable and although it's right off the street it is very quiet and peaceful. I've taken the most excellent daytime naps in there.The Innkeepers are not just nice but extremely helpful, some of their tips have saved me quite a bit of grief when trying to navigate San Francisco. As familiar as I am with SF I have found when you're unaware of events or conferences you can find yourself unpleasantly surprised in a city that likes to keep things interesting. The breakfasts here are very well thought out, the term 'continental' is misleading for their weekday breakfasts since they put out such a large variety of items you won't feel anything lacking. The weekend brunches have always been excellent even though I rarely stick around for them. The smell of french toast as I check out always lifts my spirits. Looking forward to my next visit in April

Hubby and I enjoyed staying here; we were comfortable and well looked-after. It was good to chat with visitors from the USA, Germany, France and others - interesting discussions! The building has been lovingly restored/decorated, and holds some fascinating objects and art. We found our way around SF easily by bus, which goes form around the corner from Chateau Tivoli.

Have just stayed here for 3 nights - a very different place to stay, our room was spacious but quite dark as befits this style of property. We had a very warm welcome arriving early - we left our luggage and on our return it had been taken up to our room. The afternoon wine and cheese was really nice - we managed to chat with some or the other guests which was enjoyable. The breakfast was great - again you sit at s long table so can chat with fellow guests if you choose!! Good choice of food, including homemade quiche which was interesting for breakfast!! Tea available all day. Good location and bus easy to catch into the city. We found the local restaurants a little fancy for our taste - very nice, but trendy and expensive.

We stayed here about 5 years ago on our previous trip to San Fran from Australia. That time was so good we booked in again. Once again we received a very warm welcome and s beautifully decorated room. We stayed on a Saturday night which meant that we got the great weekend cooked breakfast with champagne. We also were helped with a few things. I certainly recommend Tivoli and will stay here whenever I can.

David, Nicolas, and Bridgette are excellent hosts; the home is a grand step-back in time; and the surrounding area is an excellent location for a SF visit. We really enjoyed our stay, the hospitality, and our rooms - not a thing lacking.

this is our SF go to lodging! gorgeous inside with beautiful wooden carved staircase & themed rooms & outside painted lady! It's so great to be able to get inside a colorfully painted lady & stay the night!!great location flimore /japan town area, delish classy breakfast & afternoon wine & cheese!

Our first stop on a 6 day vaca in California. What a GREAT place! We had the Aimee Crocker room which was lovely. Arrived just as the wine and cheese time was ending (6:00 pm) but they kept it open just for us, can you say gracious? Next morning, we needed to leave before the champagne brunch (9 & 10 am) so the continental breakfast would be plenty...however, the chef came out and offered to cook some eggs for us...AND the Swiss family of 4, as well!!! Can you say, hospitality? More than what was expected on every level!!! Highly recommend!

This B&B Inn is a fine example of the late nineteenth century architecture. Originally built in 1892 by the Oregon shipping magnate, Daniel B. Jackson. The building has had an interesting history, surviving both the San Francisco earthquake of 1906 and the 60’s.The building has now been lovingly restored and it is furnished with period antiques. Making it a truly memorable experience. Cheese and wine is served in the parlour between 4 & 6 every day. We stayed in the Enrico Caruso room which had an en suite. The bed is particularly high, fortunately there was a step available, otherwise my wife would have had trouble getting into bed.Breakfast is delicious and ample. The staff were friendly and helpful in particularly David who offered us some really good advice on areas to visit.

Stayed here for about 3 nights. We took the Lilly Langtry basement suite (which is actually on the level of the road). Nice and cozy with plenty of room for the two of us. What it lacked however, was adequate natural lighting. the smaller bedroom is dark despite their lights, the main bedroom is okay. It did get cold for us one night, we had to pull the comforter off the other bed. The folks running the place, esp Nicholas, were very friendly and helpful. Good advice and instructions the day we arrived, can't thank him enough for that- saved us some money for sure!! He has done well to maintain the 'antiqueness' of the place. Weekdays was the routine continental breakfast. We could not make it to any of the wine&cheese event though. Overall, despite the shortcomings of the room, the staff made up for it. Great central location, not too far from many major attractions.

We stayed here for a couple of nights and although the layout of the rooms we were in down on the srteet level was a but odd (two double rooms sharing one bathroom )as there was 4 of us it worked out ok. The receciption rooms and lounge in the hotel were wonderfully decked out in historic funiture and pieces of art. Although it is B&B at 5pm they lay on cheese and wines free of charge in the loungewhich was very welcome.The breakfast in the morning is around a communal large table and the chief cooked up a very tasty omelet. The staff are very friendly and knowledgeable recommending a number of places to eat which we tried out.If you are after a hotel which is a bit different this ones for you.

I recently stayed at the Chateau Tivoli for a week back in January. This place exceeded all my expectations, Its such a charming house and we were delighted to find that two blocks away is the houses that they show in the opening of Full House! The staff that greeted us were incredibly helpful and never seemed bothered by all the questions we had to ask offering us maps and showed us where to find key places and important bus stops.We stayed in two rooms. First two nights we stayed in a room that had it's bathroom across the hall, I wasn't excited about this but it was actually fine. This bathroom felt very modern with victorian themes. The remaining nights we stayed in the Amy Crocker room which had a little sitting area with your quaint essential bay windows. Both rooms and the entire house seemed to be very clean and had great upkeep. The staff were generous and informative. The sour dough french toast during the weekend breakfast was great! We tried to fit everything in one week but we needed more time so we'll definitely be back!

From the moment I entered the front door until the moment I left, I was extremely happy I had chosen this place to stay. The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable about San Francisco and the area. On weekends there is a 'champagne breakfast' served. Parking can be a challenge. But you can get into town very easily on bus 5 which runs about every 3 minutes. I highly recommend this B&B

staying at Chateau Tivoli, this place is comfy, great location, wine n cheese every night, easy to hang around and relax. Heads up, there is no parking. You should plan on parking a couple blocks away at a parking garage. The weekend breakfast is fun, complented with champagne. We stayed in the Mark Twain room. You can sit at a 4 seat round table on a corner of the building looking over several streets.

We stayed for 4 night, 2 of them were in the Joaquin Miller room with the shared bathroom and 2 in Enrique Caruso with a private bathroom. If you are going to book a shared bathroom room, I suggest booking the one we stayed in, the other one (I think called Jack London) is right next to the toilet, so we walked past their room every time we needed the bathroom. It's an old house, you can hear everything. I preferred our first room to our second as it was cosier. I think that a big improvement they could make is to the breakfast offering, it's just quite poor compared to other places we have stayed at. There is lots of sugary cereal, toast, sweet breads, sweet yoghurt and even the ham was sweet probably from a glaze. Ok, so it's not to our tastes but even so having a huge hit of sugar to start the day is not good for anyone. There is some fruit but not enough. I suggest having a large fruit bowl, some boiled eggs, some healthier cereal and that would vastly improve things. I actually bought my own cereal from Whole Foods and only ate that in the end. Cheese and wine is served between 4-6pm which is great. The house has great character, it was a very cosy stay and the staff were very helpful. If they had a knock out breakfast this place would have been perfect.

My friend and I recently spent 5 nights here on our U.S. trip. We chose the 2 bedroom apartment in the basement and loved it. Staying here was like going back in time, living in the grandeur and luxury of yesteryear was wonderful. Of course with the home being hundreds of years old, there were floorboards creeking and some noises from plumbing from time to time. This was not an issue for us however. Nicholas and Meredith were lovely and made sure our stay was a pleasant one. We loved returning to the Chateau after a busy day and enjoying happy hour. This was daily from 4-6pm. A selection of wines and cheeses were on offer, a perfect way to relax and chat with other guests. We felt really at home during our stay, having run of the house and being able to enjoy all that was on offer was fabulous. Breakfast was lovely....selections of fresh fruit, bagels, breads, cold cuts, cheeses, smoked salmon and cereals were available. I would definitely stay here again.

Loved the chateau tivoli. Recently visited San Francisco with "the girls". Stayed at this lovely bed and breakfast. Loved the evening wine and cheese and the breakfast's were just what we needed to get going. The staff were awesome in helping out these clueless Canadian's..lol. Nicholas, Meredith and Janet were so helpful in their suggestions for nearby restaurants and attractions. As well as helping us with bus schedules, taxis etc. Would recommend this to any traveller going to the beautiful city of San Francisco!!

Had a very enjoyable stay. Great location within walking distance to parks and restaurants. Didn't bother with car rental as parking in SF is such a pain. Just "Ubered" it when we needed a ride. Meredith, the Innkeeper was so gracious and helpful! Really enjoyed Happy Hour wine and cheese. Loved the Luisa Tetrazinni Suite with period furniture and four poster bed! We will definitely return!

I really enjoyed my stay at the Chateau Tivoli! The building is absolutely beautiful, our room was spotless, and the staff was friendly and helpful. We stayed in the Aimee Crocker room which had a beautiful four-poster bed, outstanding wallpaper, and other fun period details. The breakfast (during the week) was basic but tasty, and we really enjoyed the wine and cheese happy hour. I would definitely stay at the Tivoli again.

Just a lovely feeling when you walk in, especially if they are serving cheese and wine which they do each evening. Beautiful, authentic furnishings and charming staff who really helped us with restaurant choices, maps, even offering to help us book our wine tour. Thanks Janet & Melinda:) wifi now available in rooms.We had 2 nights in the wonderful isadora Duncan room with a private and beautiful bathroom, then 1 night down in the Lily Langtree suite. The latter was in the basement and felt a little like it had been forced into the available space. We slept in the back bedroom as it was away from the road which gets traffic fairly early. Terrific breakfast and at weekends they provide a champagne brunch which was lovely.Great b&b experience and a chance to relax & stay in a gorgeous house in a safe and historic part of the city.

Tivoli B & B is located in a grand 1890s house a few blocks downhill from the painted ladies and Alamo Square. Many of the interior architectural features remain in the spacious parlor, stair hall, and dining room, and the furnishings complement the over-the-top period architecture. We stayed in a fairly large room with 3 windows on the third floor for 1 night. We couldn't get wifi in that room, but that was not an issue for us, and I expect wifi worked in the rooms downstairs. The bathroom was shared with one other room. The bathtub and hand held shower under a sloped ceiling was a challenge, even for an average height person, as the innkeeper had warned us. We enjoyed a weekend champagne breakfast with very good french toast, bacon and fruit. The innkeepers were very nice and helpful.

We stayed for 4 nights in the Jack London room. Lovely clean room, with a table and chairs set in the turret... yes the turret! Wi-Fi was no problem in the room, able to stream videos. If you want to watch anything you'll have to do it via the internet as there is no TV. The breakfast was really good, continental during the week and a champagne breakfast with cooked bacon and eggs at the weekend. But best of all were the staff who will bend over backwards for you and give you as many recommendations as you require. Special shout out to Meredith!Great value for San Francisco

The place is beautiful inside and out..The weekday breakfasts are nice - continental but not just a pastry and some coffee. They provide cream cheese, excellent jams, yogurt, and granola. There is free wi-fi, but it may not reach all rooms.

The place is beautiful inside and out.We stayed in the Jack London room on the 3rd floor - long climb, but worth it. Nonetheless, we're likely to to stay in a second floor room the next time - the stairs to the 3rd floor are steep! The weekday breakfasts are nice - continental but not just a pastry and some coffee. They provide cream cheese, excellent jams, yogurt, and granola. The weekend champagne brunch is more elaborate - french toast, bacon, and fresh fruit. Not to mention the champagne.The afternoon wine & cheese is nice, although not as social as some I've seen at B&Bs - that is a question of the clientele, not the staff as far as I can see.Big disadvantage here is parking - it's all street and will be requiring a visitor permit at some point later in 2015. We didn't mind, we're used to street parking in Baltimore. Also, the inn is located close to several major public transit arteries, so a car may not be necessary.There is free wi-fi, but it may not reach all rooms.

We stayed in two different rooms during our stay. This mansion is very much in the original, or close to, from its historical past. Beautiful atmosphere and decor. The Inn keeper (Meredith) and Inn Manager (Nicholas) were fantastic. The breakfast was awesome. Later in the afternoon wine and cheese are available. Delicious and a great presentation. One of the quest played the lobby piano while we relaxed upstairs in our room. It was amazing. We highly recommend this B&B. We will return in the future. To us it was worth every cent.

For folks who love history, this is a great place to stay. We stayed in the Mark Twain room on the top of 3 floors. The room was huge and lots of fun to be in. The whole house was full of period furniture and decor, and the hosts were helpful without intruding. We enjoyed staying here and exploring a house built in another, grander, time.

Almost hate to let the cat out of the bag and tell people how wonderful this little bed and breakfast is. What a score! It is elegant, well decorated, superb service, really great location just a block from the painted ladies, filled with charm, history and character. Don't think I'll ever stay at another hotel when I'm in San Francisco. Reasonable room rates. One negative that does go along with the territory: offstreet parking is all they have. However, it is well worth the trade-off for what you get.

Had a wonderful stay in September at the Chateau Tivoli B & B. Relaxing, friendly, knowledgable and great staff! Free cheese and wine every evening. Great sightseeing and shopping in walking distance. Would love to go back!

Basically, if they've availability, book it. We stayed just two nights and wished we could have stayed longer. We stayed in the Isadora Duncan room which had it's own private bathroom across the corridor. Which almost put us off making the booking but in fact it was more than fine, the bathroom was huge and very tastefully decorated. It was literally three steps from our room.The room was on the first floor and overlooked Steiner Street. The bed was comfortable and huge. All the furnishings were very high quality and sympathetic to this historical mansion. The room had very tall ceilings and had some lovely artwork. The rooms have no minibar or television in keeping with the style of the accommodation.The parlour, where cheese and wine were served every afternoon was a delight, with comfortable period furniture, a piano, interesting ornamentation and a vintage valve radio playing classical music. The parlour leads onto the dining room where breakfast was served at a communal table and also at a table for two. It's a continental breakfast and is very good. You can also use the kitchen which is out back behind the dining room. If you want to cook or keep things cold in the fridge.Staying in an historical mansion was a unique experience for us and was one of the highlights of our holiday.Parking is quite hard to come by if you arrive in the afternoon, we had to park three blocks away. However it's free. Also, we we warned by a member of staff not to walk through a nearby block close by. Think it was Filmore Street. That freaked us out a bit. We felt safe in the immediate neighbourhood though and used public transport without any bother.Chateau Tivoli is not central, but their is a bus stop nearby and the Haight neighbourhood was in walking distance. We walked back one afternoon from the city centre and it was a leisurely one hour stroll.All in all we had a fantastic experience.

The Chateau is very romantic as you can see on the photos, beautiful decoration, details on every wall...the furniture, the hole place has this style. Near of Alamo Square, at least three lines of buses around two walking blocks. There is also a parking lot for $25 day. The breakfast is delicious and there's the happy hour with cheese, wine and some delicatesen.Recommended 100%

Our second visit and it was lovely to be welcomed back like old friends. It was good to see Nico & Meredith again and they couldn't have been more helpful - we could only stay one night on this trip but they let us drop our luggage off early the day we arrived and kept it for us until late afternoon the day we left. Meredith also arranged a very reasonably priced limo transfer to the airport for us. Hope to stay longer on our next visit to San Francisco.

Nice B&B. Friendly staff, always ready to help. The building is really impressive. We reserved a room with a shared bathroom because it was the only one left, but finally it was not an issue at all. We were pleased with our stay. The brunch breakfast on the weekends is amazing. By walk, you have access to a few nice restaurants. I recommend.

We spent 5 days in the Lily Langtree suite and could not have found a more delightful place to stay in San Francisco.The Chateau is beautiful, quirky, classy and full of character. The decor is fits the era and the whole feel is calm and dignified.Our suite was advertised as being "in the basement", but with the hilly nature of the area, we had windows at street level and our own private door onto the street.Even though the word "suite" was used when we booked, we expected, for the reasonable price we paid, to get a room and possibly a hallway, but we ended up with two bedrooms and two hallways !The continental breakfasts were great and there was complimentary cheese and wine laid out in the reception rooms every afternoon - with the antique radiogram tuned to the classical station. We did not stay long enough to sample the weekend champagne breakfasts, sadly.The B&B is near Alamo Square and the (now dull pastel) Painted Ladies. The #5 bus passes by regularly a half a block away and goes to town (Market Street) one way and the Botanical Gardens and Ocean View beach the other way. Fillmore and its restuarants and jazz is a short walk down the hill and Divisadero street with its shops and coffee bars is a walk of several quite steep blocks the other way.The Chateau has free wi-fi, though the signal is only strong in the reception rooms. We could get a signal from our toilet ! But there are plenty of chairs, tables and settees to settle into in the sitting room upstairs - with a glass of good wine if you choose your time right.On top of all this - the staff were wonderful. Friendly, helpful, chatty, kind, full of suggestions.... They made the stay that much more special. Thank you Meredith and Nick.Beware. There are no TV's in the B&B. There suggestion is that if you need to be entertained, they have board games and plenty of books to read. Somehow this made things even more specially and classy and got us out and about more than we might have done normally.Top tip for San Francisco if you don't have a car: Buy a visitor pass for the Muni transport.You pay $3 for a Clipper card and then load it with either a 1-day, 3-day or 7-day pass. This means you can travel on all the buses, trams and trolleys, whenever you like. It does not cover the BART (underground) however, but we never found the need to use this anyway.

My family and I stayed for 3 nights at this delightful B&B. It's very quirky and charming. The rooms are lovely (and no TV - how fantastic. You don't go on holiday to watch TV anyway.) I normally sleep very badly in hotels, but our bed was extremely comfortable. The B&B is a bit outside of the centre of SF, but once you have got the hang of public transport it isn't a problem. And frankly staying in the centre of the city is very noisy. Breakfast was fantastic, as was the cheese and wine every afternoon. Overall a great visit. I thoroughly recommend the Chateau Tivoli.

We had an awesome room here. Well appointed and the breakfast was good. It is such a unique place to stay in SF. The room was a little expensive at ~$200 per night, but many places in SF are much more expensive.

Stayed here late October 2013. We were in the Jack London room. Very tidy and the turret was super cute! Only problem I found with room was lack of power sockets near bed, but I guess that comes with and older building. Sharing the bathroom with the room next door was never an issue, and if we were desperate there was a bathroom available on the main level. The bathroom was nice and there was plenty of shampoo, conditioner, soap, etc. Bathtub has a handheld shower head but I found I was too tall and had to kneel in the bath to wash my hair! Third floor staircase is skinny and it was a little hard dragging our luggage up there.Staff were so friendly and helpful. Were happy to hold our luggage for us when we checked out and let us wait in lounge area in evening as we had a very late flight. Dressed up for Halloween too which was cool! The breakfast was delicious and there was quite a lot to choose from. Good location, five minutes from Alamo Square. We would walk down to Pier 39 etc in morning and then taxi home in the evening after our day for a reasonable price. Overall I loved it here. I've stayed in a LOT of hotels in the USA and this is my favourite. The building is absolutely gorgeous and it was like being transported back to a different era. Would definitely stay here again!

Chateau Tivoli is a boutique hotel / guesthouse in San Francisco. The building, its interior, its decoration scream original period detail. The hotel has modern creature comforts such as wifi and en-suite bathrooms, but other than that you feel blissfully transported back to another era.It is a period building, so there is no double glazing and no air conditioning (i.e. expect some noise from the street, but not enough to disturb your sleep).Breakfast is served at a large shared dining table, with only one table for two in the window bay. Therefore you need to be able to put on a "morning face" and chat with your fellow guests over breakfast (this will either be your heaven or your hell, depending on your personal taste). The breakfast menu is simple but delicious. Expect bucks fizz with breakfast on Sunday mornings.Complimentary cheese and wine are served mid-afternoon, and the selection is generous.The staff are helpful and friendly, but discrete and not in your face.We enjoyed our stay here, and would happily stay there again. It is a little outside of the main tourist drag, but is close enough to a good selection of restaurants, the Castro and public transport.

We only needed a place to stay for one night and are glad we came across this reasonably-priced Bed and Breakfast. As we had just come into town very early in the morning after a cruise, we were happy that Meredith of the Chateau welcomed us in the morning and allowed us to keep our luggage there while we explored the city for the day.She even offered us breakfast which was very nice - lots of selections for everyone's breakfast desires. There were two types of cereals, yogurt, bagels, bread slices, quiche, fresh fruit salads, smoked salmon with capers and onions, etc. Coffee, tea, juice and water also available.We stayed in the basement suite which consisted of a little kitchen, two bedrooms and a bathroom. The heritage of this large home is incredibly well-kept - I wish we could have stayed longer to get a good look at the whole place. The main floor has a large sitting areaAlthough this place is not that close to town, it is very easy to get there by bus or bicycle. For us, the price was right, the ambience was so pleasant, and we enjoyed meeting some of the others staying there.The innkeeper offered to print off our boarding passes for our flight which was very much appreciated.

Because our youngest son was with us for two of our three night stay at Chateau Tivoli, we chose the Lola Montez "basement economy suite." It was a superb choice: The suite was spacious, comfortable, and quite affordable. Because of its private entrance, the basement suite was well-suited for our bicycles, our primary means of travel while in "The Cool Gray City of Love." My sole criticism of the "basement economy suite" is that the lovely original woodwork could use a fresh coat of paint!Meredith, the innkeeper, is the very model of professionalism, competence, and friendliness. She also prepares and serves outstanding breakfasts (the recent review complaining about the quality of the weekday breakfast leaves me baffled!).Chateau Tivoli's location was ideal for our two-wheeled exploration of the remarkable neighborhoods and architecture in what is surely one of the two or three most iconic of all American cities--a place quite easy "to leave your heart in" and one to which we hope to return again in the near future.

I was apprehensive about booking this property, but I'm so happy with our decision to stay here. The rooms are fine, the location is amazing, and there is free parking. There are dozens of nearby restaurants and walking distance to so much. And the staff (Irene) went above and beyond to meet our family needs and changed us to a 2BR suite that worked much better for us. A friend offered us a suite at the Ritz which we declined in favor of remaining at the Cow Hollow.

The room was spacious and it worked for us. We didn't spend a lot of time in the room because we were on the go a lot. The bed was comfortable but the pillows were bad. The bathroom was very clean and large. I prefer staying somewhere off the beaten path, but this is right in the city. On the other hand, it was close to most of the things we wanted to do, it had free parking, it was clean and had good restaurants within walking distance. Over all, we were very happy with the hotel.

The location was good and the parking was nice but everything else was not worth the money. The beds were very uncomfortable and the noise from outside was like the windows were wide open. If I had not brought earplugs I would not have slept.

Great location-- been staying at the hotel for years. But it is fading-- needs updating. Too bad-- needs paint and new furnishings and beds. The internet is terrible-- to save money (I guess) they only have a couple routers. I had to go to the coffee shop to get work done. Not able to use the most basic internet functions.

Excellent motel for the money and convenient location! Excellent parking facilities, the only downside was breakfast was not included, but there are many excellent restaurants located nearby. Highly recommended facility, quiet, clean and comfortable rooms!

The Cow Hollow Inn is a 3 star establishment ( in my books ) , tired , old , with not much in the way of charm but fastidiously clean and tidy . Ok so the reception is in the garage area . And you have to walk across the parking area to get the lift. But although the furnishings are tired in appearance but certainly not stained or threadbare,, the rooms are large and beautifully groomed and cleaned to the nth degree. For cleanliness and presentation the C.H. Inn is without peer . I often stay here for the price but mainly the cleanliness . It is on a busy road but only 5mins from Chestnut Street with its bars and boutique shops. A lovely neighbourhood.I recommend this hotel at this pricepoint . And the diner across the road !

We stayed 3 nights here in June with 2 little kids. We stayed on the 3rd floor and had a sizable room with a decent bathroom. I wish it had a fridge and a microwave but we managed without it. The location was great as it is close to a ton of restaurants and a few parks. It was about a 1.5 mile walk to the Fisherman's Wharf area but does not involve any huge hills. The free parking underneath the hotel is incredible for the San Francisco area.

The room was very large and was well maintained. Shower worked perfectly, bed was comfortable and the room had nice AC. Free parking was great and made this a really excellent stay. Front desk staff was well trained and quick as well.

They didn’t make up room Tuesday, and said it was because we had the do not disturb sign up, but that was only true for an hr in am and from 3-5 in pm. When we complained, at 5:00 they said it was too late. They asked if we needed anything and we said towels. They asked about coffee and we said yes. So when we returned from dinner they had given us small towels (no big ones) and only coffee … no clean cups or sugar! Not great!Our room was lovely and large, but had a view of an air shaft!

Spent two nights here. We liked the location. Free parking was a huge bonus. The street is noisy at night, but w/air conditioning running, the noise did not bother us at all. Walking distance to The Palace of the Arts. Motel was clean. I’d recommend this place— reasonable price. I’d stay again! The restaurant next door, Home Plate was a delicious breakfast.

Room was clean and large with coffee facilities. It was near numerous restaurants and cafes ( 2 minutes) to at least 15. Hop on hop off bus stopped across the road . I walked to the Alcatraz dock which took about 40 minutes. About 15 to get to the Bay and then you can explore various directions and see The Gokden Gate Bridge. Would stay here again. If you drive though be aware parking is a little compact ...check it out with front desk who appear to organise

The Cow Hollow Inn makes a great base for exploring San Francisco. It is inexpensive compared with most downtown hotels yet it is clean and comfortable. Nearby Chestnut St is full of cafes, restaurants and small shops and there is a good bus service to get to Fisherman's Wharf and other locations. The tour buses pick up from this location too. There was some road noise but not enough to keep me awake. Cow Hollow and the adjoining Marina district have a safe neighborhood feel and there are great views of the Golden Gate bridge from the nearby Marina park

We stayed here for 2 nights and it was great. Rooms are really spacious and clean. Bed was comfortable. Location was perfect, lots of bars, restaurants etc close by. Within walking distance to fisherman’s wharf!! Also has parking included.

We have stayed here twice before and on both occasions have found the hotel excellent in every way. The rooms are extremely spacious, very high quality and comfortable too. Parking is inclusive and always appears to be plenty of room. The staff are extremely efficient, friendly and helpful when any information is required.The hotel is within walking distance (1 mile) of some of the major attractions Pier 39, cable cars etc; Golden gate bridge is approx 2 miles from the hotel.This is certainly our hotel of choice in San Francisco and I'd highly recommend it for anyone visiting the city.

Excellent room for a family of 3, we stayed here twice when we visited SF. Good access and on a main bus route (28) to get into Pier 39 or Golden gate bridge. Only downside was breakfast(not included) and the huge queue for the restaurant next door,(but apparently it is very good so worth it) but we you do have access to Chester street where there is more than enough choice of food and nice and vibrant..quiet and safe neighbourhood we had no issue at walking around early morning or later in the evening

I have stayed here several times over the years and each time is an enjoyable experience. We traveled here to go to the Giants game and they were gracious enough to allow us to check into our room early before the game. Great value. Great service. Nice quiet room off the street.

This was much nicer than we expected. Room very nice and clean. Good location and lots of good restaurants nearby. Our room was a little noisey at night with traffic and road construction but not terrible.Close to public transportation, which is the only way to go.My husband uses a wheelchair and there was a roomy elevator to our 2nd floor room.Staff was pleasant.

very good accommodations in a well located area with free parking. We were able to catch a bus only a block away and ride to the Fisherman's Wharf where we could, among other things, visit Ghiradellies and ride a cable car.

Near everything; easy walking to very good restaurants. Nice staff and safe area, and we had no 'noise' issues. Our top floor corner room was perfect & so much so that we would book another room there in a heartbeat.

The access to Cow Hollow is very easy off Lombard street. There is a direct turn into parking garage off Lombard, and another off Steiner St. The garage was very clean with access to the office and elevators. The office staff were very pleasant and we were allowed into our room 2 hours early! Most places will not do this. Our room was fine and very clean. The bathroom has a lot of space and counter space for toiletries. There is a heater, in the ceiling, for after shower chills. The closet was ample and there is a room safe which we used (very convenient). We were facing Lombard St. As other reviewers have discussed, it was noisy. And, another reviewer was correct that there are rooms facing off the main drag but with an additional fee of $10. I think you have to put this in perspective. Hotels sometimes charge more for a pool view or an ocean view or how high up your room is. This is no different. And, I feel badly that someone smeared the staff. They were great! If you want more quiet, pay the $10. The room is already a bargain by SF standards and a good one at that. If not, bring your eye mask and ear plugs and turn your phone on white noise and I bet you would be ok. The area, around the hotel is very safe and walkable to all kinds of restaurants, shops and bars. I had not explored this area before. All in all, a great place to stay!

Beware of the bait and switch! On our first visit to the Cow Hollow Inn we were given a room was facing Lombard Street. For those who are not familiar with San Francisco, Lombard aka U.S. 101 which goes through town and over the Golden Gate Bridge and is one of the busier thoroughfares in the city. If your room is on Lombard you will hear a pretty constant stream of car and truck traffic. The hotel is nothing fancy, but more expensive than a similar two star hotel in other cities. Remember it is San Francisco! Our kids live a few blocks from the hotel so it is convenient. On our second visit to the cow Hollow Inn, I noticed a couple of things on the website when I was making my reservation. They offer, Standard, Deluxe and Superior rooms with relative increasing rates. Typically this means bigger rooms, maybe a sofa etc. Links to the room descriptions were broken. I got that 404 error message. I was content with the standard room price. They also had a drop down list of requests. For example you could ask for a room on the 1st, Floor, 2nd Floor, 3rd Floor, "Back Room If Possible", Crib, Early Arrival, Extra Pillow, Foam Pillow… etc. Oh yea refrigerator $5.00 per day. I thought that was nice so I requested a back room and foam pillow.On the day before we were to arrive I received a call from the hotel confirming my reservation, acknowledging that I had requested a back room. They mentioned that I had selected a standard room and that the back rooms are deluxe or better so if I wanted a back room away from Lombard, it would be $10 more per day.I told them I was confused because the website did not indicate a surcharge for a back room request, nor a surcharge for any other request except if I wanted a refrigerator. I told them that I found their request offensive and that it seemed like a shake down for more money. I ask them to grant my request for a back room (they already indicated it was possible) and that I should not be charged. They said that they could not honor this request, but they would pass on my concern to the owners. When I checked in the next day we were located in a room facing Lombard and no foam pillow. I am one of those foolish people that does not like to complain all the time on small issues so I did not. At the same respect I do not like to take be taken advantage of either.. The hotel was clean, but had an antiseptic smell in the halls…sort of like a hospital. The house keeping staff was efficient and the room was cleaned promptly, though low grade shampoo and conditioner.It is not much money, but probably an indication of the owners mindset. I am choosing to vote with my dollars and will be selecting another hotel for our next visit to the kids.If you must stay at the Cow Hollow Inn, beware of the noise on Lombard and the sneaky front desk staff looking to up-charge you for a simple request. Cheers!

Very nice rooms and friendly staff, but they gave us a room facing Lombard street and found very noisy due to traffic.The underground parking was a nice feature and rooms very clean and spacious, also close to wharf and other amenities. But if loud noises from the street traffic would bother you I would not recommend this hotel.

Bad, broken AC/heat. They don’t honor AAA anymore. NO mini fridge, they said it would be additional $5.00 even the coffee maker had no place to plug in. I have been coming to this Hotel for years and don’t understand why the rates went up and the hospitality went down.

We (2 couples) stayed at the Cow Hollow Inn & Suites for 3 nights at the start of our California Adventure. We booked a 2 Bedroom/2 Bathroom Suite, complete with Full Living Room, Dining Table and Kitchen. We stayed in the 3rd Floor of the Blair Building and could not have been happier with our choice.Clean and comfortable Suite, with plenty of room for the four of us. Free covered parking, with easy elevator access, included in the rate. And, the location was terrific!Plenty of Restaurants, Bars and Shopping within the surrounding blocks. Easy to get to the Fisherman's Wharf area, as well as other sites we wanted to see.Finally, the reservation person (we booked directly with Cow Hollow) and Check-In Desk folks were friendly and helpful.Just remember, San Francisco is an expensive hotel market. Cow Hollow Inn & Suites, while not low budget, was very fairly priced. You can't go wrong with this property.Only two suggestions: Main A/C Unit is in Living Room, so the two Bedrooms could use Fans; and,don't go to Mel's Diner (across the street) it's terrible.

My husband and I have been staying at this hotel a lot over the last five years. Medical needs have made it necessary to stay two or three days at least every three months. I have ALS and can no longer speak and it is difficult to walk. Because of that I always ask for a certain room close to the elevator. This time when we checked in we were given a different room. I wrote a note to the person helping me and was then scolded for thinking that we could always have that room. We accepted a different room and upon checking in thought it was fine. I unpacked our clothes and set up the equipment for a feeding tube. Finally put on my robe and I had stockings on. It was then that we realized that the carpet was wet! My socks were soaked! I wrote an email expressing our dismay with the situation. This was at 3:30. No response at all. The next morning I see where this woman responded at 11:00 last night. Again, spent most of her time scolding over the room number although in my note, I said the room was fine, it was the wet carpet that was the problem. We had a choice...we could get a king bed on a noisy street or two double beds. Nothing whatsoever to apologize for our wet floor! We will not stay here again. The woman, Irene, could have cared less that I am handicapped and could not speak to explain our issues. The hotel is fine, but not with the woman who manages check ins!

Great motel type accommodation, easy free car parking on site, easy access to rooms from car park, rooms are well appointed for a city break, good size, clean & comfortable, bathroom has all necessities. Nice location away from down town, near Bay Area & wharf, great little shops & restaurants around corner, attached restaurant very good, will differently stay here again

We’ve stayed here a few times before, great location and clean place to stay. We usually ask for a room off Lombard, but this visit for some reason the outside noise was more noticeable this time, it sounded like our room was just above a bar. Unfortunately this time we left behind a bag of items, containing about $100 worth of items. It was a gift given to us by a family friend and we inadvertently left it sitting on the dresser. We realized the next morning as we were unpacking we had left the bag at the hotel. I called the hotel and the hotel receptionist said the items were not turned in by hotel staff and she said they were more than likely thrown out. The hotel receptionist said she would contact the staff member who had cleaned our room that day and get back to us. We never heard back. It’s hard to believe our bag of items had been thrown out as the times were all unopened. Sad to think we would have been better off leaving the bag in our car in the hotel garage! I know it’s our fault for leaving the bag but unfortunate staff just discards items left behind.

The positives for this hotel are the free underground parking as parking in San Fran is very difficult and can be expensive. We parked our car up here and then used UBER's to get around which were very efficient. Also, the cafe downstairs (not related) called Home Plate is a perfect place to get breakfast. However the staff were not very friendly, in fact they were quite rude and dismissive on our arrival, and the room was quite old fashioned and needed some updating, hence the three stars. Average hotel.

A great value hotel, which I would highly recommend. We had a room at the front of the hotel and yes it is a busy road but we really didn't notice the noise too much! The hotel is in a great position, within walking distance of some major sights and unbelievable restaurants.I can't recommend Home Plate next year enough for breakfast!

This is a really good place to stay. Very clean. Good beds. Big room. Parking garage. Great location on Lombard St and easy walking to the waterfront. There is no restaurant in the hotel but a really good eating place downstairs.

Business trip so I didn’t have many requirements beyond a clean quiet room. Check in was smooth and efficient. Room was very clean and comfortable. Parking was easy. Lots of varied places nearby to eat.

Our room was lively, office staff Fanny and Tracy were so warm and friendly. Fanny helped us get our first Uber experience. Eat next store at Home Plate best breakfast. Parking in building. They make it easy to stay. Will be back

We arrived in SF on 4 October 2018; being the final part of our trip having previously visited Vegas and San Diego. We took the Bart from the airport (the machines to buy the tickets are very confusing and looked to be set up so ou would overpay) to embarcadero as recommended on this very site and got a taxi to the hotel after eventually finding the right entrance from the station. Overall cost was $35 for the two of us. The room wasn't ready until 4 o clock but we could leave our bags in a secure room. We were in room 333 which as requested on booking directly was on the top floor at the back of the hotel. The room was lovely, very comfortable, had a view of golden gate bridge and had a coffee machine. The hotel is in a fantastic position with lots of bars and restaurants on chestnut st or union st. We had breakfast at Noahs' bagels which was really good and highly recommended. Fisherman's wharf is in walking distance though we generally used the number 30 bus which goes there and then onto union square (We got a weekly pass for $37 which was an absolute bargain as you can also use it on the cable cars which are $7a trip alone). Only thing to watch out with the number 30 bus is that the 30x doesn't go to union square and the 30s on the way back only goes as far as van Ness. The hotel offered a shuttle to the airport for $17 each but this picks up at other hotels and we were told to allow two hours for the journey so got an uber ($55) instead. Would definitely stay at this hotel if we ever returned to the best city we have ever been to in the USA.

I had a one day business trip to SFO and needed a downtown hotel that wouldn't break the budget. My room was very reasonably priced (under $400/night after taxes, etc.). The staff was friendly. The room is not super modern, but it was clean and comfortable, especially after a cross-country flight. The noise was not terrible if you are used to city traffic. There is a terrific restaurant next door for breakfast where you get a discount for staying at the hotel.

None professional, place holds on your card without letting you know. Then I contacted manager he was rude and yelled and was completely unprofessional.The rooms are not bad, but they are not suites. They are Motel 6 at best. Then add bad customer support, hidden fees and a rude and unprofessional manager. I will never stay here again and would warn anyone off doing so.

There are a lot of places to stay in San Francisco, many of them scorchingly expensive, particularly when a big convention is in town. Then there are out-of-the way places that are, in fact, really good, both in quality and location. Cow Hollow Inn and Suites is one of them. Actually it's in a very lively part of the city - near Union Street and Chestnut Street, both destinations for locals search for life and food. It's also a short walk from Fort Mason. Lombard Street leads straight to the iconic Golden Gate Bridge, so it gets a lot of traffic. We stayed here because we didn't want to pay $1000 per night in the middle of town during a major convention. It was a great decision. Cow Hollow is very comfortable and has great staff. If you have a car (we didn't) it also as terrific parking. Lots of restaurants nearby and the city itself is just an Uber away. If you like quiet, it is best to pay a bit extra for an inside room. We did and slept like logs. Silence is wonderful. Check out Mel's diner across the street for breakfast. You can't go wrong.

I booked online at Booking.com, and immediately after realized I didn't actually need the room, as friends were able to put us up. I called right away and asked if they could please make an exception to their online booking no-cancellation policy, as I had made a mistake. The desk receptionist said I would have to wait for the manager, who wouldn't be back until the next day. The manager was adamant that she would not make an exception, insisting that I could only change the date and not cancel. I explained that I wouldn't need the room on any other date because we were moving to the area. She said that was all she was willing to do, as there was a no cancellation policy. No cancellation policies exist so there won't be last-minute cancellations where you can't fill the room - I called immediately, so this is just her insisting on keeping the $300 for a booking I couldn't even keep. So we kept the room, even though we didn't need it, and since we were both laid up with the flu, we stayed with our friends instead of checking into the hotel that night. I just checked my credit card statement and there's an inexplicable $8.00 charge from this hotel. For what? Why? Why would they do that? It's not the amount of money that matters but they already HAD $300 I could ill afford and now they charge me $8 for no reason at all? We weren't even THERE, what could we possibly have done to merit a charge? I called to ask what the charge was for and the receptionist said he didn't know, he'd have to ask the manager. OH GOOD can't wait to deal with that penny-pinching jerk again, can't wait to hear why she charged me $8 in addition to the $300 I paid for a room she probably went ahead and rented to someone else so she could double her money. Their hold music, by the way, promises a "friendly and accommodating" staff. They've been anything but friendly and accommodating. They've been useless without this manager and the manager has been a straight-up epithet. I don't know what the rooms are like and I don't care - the management is a piece of work.

Arrived way to early for our two day stay. Easy to find and you simply drive directly in to the reception. Amazing!We parked the car directly under the Hotel next to the reception. We were warmly welcomed by an mature Asia looking gentleman. He really made os feel welcome and was sorry that our room was not ready. He then stored our language and gave us several maps and tips to explore the City. In general a very nice person.Returning in the afternoon, LYN were then in the reception. This job could be over her head. A solution could be customer service training, Added with simple manors. Never have my girlfriend and I experienced such poor / arrogant / rude service.The room turned out to be great. Huge with comfortable bed, clean and limited noise from Lombard street. Coffee and tee Facilities, large TV and spacious bathrooms.The area offers many restaurants and shopping opportunities, in walking distance.Strong WIFI and free parking. Breakfast not available, however many choices just around the corner.Will be back if in the area again.

Our room was basic, but clean and comfortable. We did have a room more prone to noise, but the thermostat's fan setting helped greatly, and we noticed it was noisier on the Saturday night we were there than the weekdays. Location was great with shopping, restaurants, coffee, walk ability and transit. And thanks to the free parking, we parked the car and didn't feel bad for never using it until we left.

Location of this hotel is spot on, the Cow Hollow area felt very safe and there were plenty of good restaurants and bars to visit in the evening. You could walk into Fishermans Wharf/Union Square without problem or Uber was also very reasonable price. Rooms were a great size too for San Francisco and the free parking was a major bonus. On the downside was the road noise, if you are staying in a room that is on Lombard Street then ear plugs are a must, it did quieten down at night but still wasn't great and the traffic started again very early, better glazing is needed. I only really dealt with one member of staff during our stay and afraid to say that the level of customer service was not great, didn't seem interested or helpful with the few issues we had.

An out dated room.Badly in need of double glazing.It was like sleeping on the side of the highway.The hotel was clean.The surrounding area was over run by university aged young people, the surrounding restaurants very expensive and packed. If staying in San Francisco i would advise to stay in the fishermens wharf area. The biggest tip for staying in San Francisco in August is pack your jeans and Sweatshirts, we were so cold and damp most of the time! Visiting Union square and Alcatraz a must.

The Cow Hollow Inn and Suites is our go to place in SF. The rooms are comfortable and the neighborhood is awesome! Great food and shopping. Super easy bus access or Uber anywhere if you like. We stay here every year at Christmas and any other time we visit SF

Excellent time spent here in the heart of Cow Hollow! My old stomping grounds when I lived in this neighborhood!Extra nice to have free covered parking as well. Clean, spacious room. Perfect location to see all the sights, nice walkable area to great restaurants and bars.

The hotel is on Lombard St., a block away from Chestnut St., the main drag in the Marina area. The area is lovely with many pastel-colored old buildings with decorated exteriors. It is near Marina Green and Fort Mason and the Presidio (drive or take a bus to the latter). The rooms are large and quiet (but try to stay away from Lombard).

We love the Cow Hollow and always stay there when is SF. We love the neighborhood and all the Chestnut Street restaurants and shops and the marina district. The motel is basic, but you don’t go to sf to stay in the room. But if you do you may want another place.

We considered multiple TripAdvisor reviews and activity mapping when considering lodging options for our five day trip to San Francisco. Our overarching goal was to find a hotel which was centralized between our scheduled activities and our oldest son's home. We found the Cow Hollow Inn and Suites to be in the perfect location.We found the hotel staff to be extremely professional and courteous during our stay. The manager's recommendations for breakfast and lunch were outstanding and greatly appreciated. We used the rental car very little and having the garage made for a safe parking location.The hotel may be a bit outdated but it was very comfortable and the room was spacious. We visited the Blue Barn, Home Plate and Pete's Coffee & Tea which were each fantastic and literally only steps away. Plenty of high end shopping one block away which was very much enjoyed by certain members of the family. NOTE: This is an expensive trip so plan accordingly!Pack your sneakers! The best way to see the sights are on foot if you are able to do so - we walked to Crissy Field multiple times per day, to the base of the Golden Gate Bridge and to Fisherman's Wharf. We put on plenty of walking mileage during the trip - we also traveled the PCH by car and used Uber for an early morning departure to the Alcatraz Ferry.We will absolutely be returning to Cow Hollow Inn and Suites summer 2019!

What a great place to stay! We were really pleased with our choice, great neighbourhood with lots of bars and restaurants. The hotel was well located for our sightseeing. Reception staff were friendly and helpful. Our room was huge with a lovely big comfy bed. Highly recommended.

It's not glitzy, but the Cow Hollow Inn is quaint little place to stay. It's well managed, in a good location, affordable, and adorable. Probably a great place to stay if you have a family. It's a short walk from a lot of diners and a not-too-far from the water.

I visited San Francisco in July and stayed at the Cow Hollow Inn. You’re not sure what to expect from the outside, but it was a pleasant surpriseThe rooms have been recently updated. The site is secure. The location extremely convenient. Within walking distance to several restaurants if you can’t try the one they have, coffee shops and storesA quick ride to all the famous points of interest and they even have a parking garage if you’ve brought your own carGet a room that’s not on Lombard to avoid the “hustle and bustle” noise.

We stayed here 3 nights during our vacation. This is a great choice if you drive to San Francisco since the parking is free. Great neighbourhood, not too touristy, within reach to main attractions with bus/ trolleybus 28 and 30. Would stay here again.

This hotel was clean, and the rate was decent, which is why I’m giving it 2 stars.The hotel isn’t very close to any tourist spots, we took Uber or the city bus wherever we wanted to go. And my biggest complaint was the noise. We were in the 2nd floor and could hear every vehicle driving by as well as any conversation people were having walking down the street. The noise will keep you up all night!

Great location and we were happy to support a family owned business. A family friend recommended this place since they stay here every time they come to town. Clean rooms and pretty friendly staff. The only downside was our room faced Lombard and the traffic noise at night was very loud!

We booked 3 nights, booked 2 rooms for 3 teens and 2 parents for this part of our summer family trip. The hotel is so close to amazing restaurants( smaller sized ) coffee/ ice-cream shops convenient store and shopping, less than 5 minute walk!!! Fun to walk to walk to one " hub" and 4th of July fireworks at the crowded pier area, took about 20 - 30 minutes. Hotel room was clean and pretty spacious. Dated but didn't bother me. Parking included was a very nice feature. Desk was helpful and friendly.

I hesitate to write this because I don't want to jinx the availability for when I want to return...but this place is great! Large room, fridge for an extra $5 per night (no micro, that's my only complaint) and free parking. I paid the extra for a premium (quiet) room and it was worth it. But the best park is the location, which I had no idea about when we booked it! In the Marina area, walking distance to the Wharf, and surrounded by the cutest neighborhood with restaurants, coffee shops- even a Walgreens! Oh, and comfortable king size bed and lots of TV stations. I wanna bring my mom friends and come back!

Everything about staying at the GG Hotel made San Francisco better. Great location near to shopping good restaurants. The staff were most welcoming and helpful. Breakfast was good - quite French. And they went out of their way to ensure good service was provided.

I was quite fond of this place by the time i checked out after 5 nights. It reminds me a bit of a British sit-com, yes the hotel is a teeny fusty in style, but as a solo female traveler, i appreciated its cozy comforts with its close hallways and rooms. Lots of nice service when I checked in, but then they leave you alone. I am not the sort who loves talking to strangers over breakfast, so their parlor style, with a variety of table shapes and sizes suited me. The resident cat Pip charmed me each morning as he sat in a chair and stared my coffee and me. My ONLY quibble with this hotel was the 8 am start time for breakfast, which is a bit late for some of us reluctant early risers. But the coffee, croissants and juice were worth the wait.

Stayed here for a third time simply because we love the location and the people. We started our trip with 4 nights here and returned for our final night. Comfortable, clean and quiet for a good nights sleep. Whether it is Dora at breakfast, Spencer at check in or Halim thereafter, all 3 are a credit to this place. Particularly enjoyed our chat with Halim, he is a gem with 37 years at this place.

We recently stayed for 1 night in this very welcoming hotel in San Francisco. They really go the extra mile to make you feel welcome. they provide tea and biscuits at 4 pm for guests - you can sit in the parlour and meet other guests. The breakfast is very nice and you can share tables with other guests. Most rooms have a bathroom but ours did not - which I knew when I booked. The shared facility was just a few steps from our door. Each room has its own sink. We arrived early and were able to check in early - great after a long flight. We will definitely stay there again.

I have stayed here 8 times in the past 9 years. I much prefer the cozy rooms and friendly atmosphere to a hotel chain. Shared bathroom isn’t for everyone but in all my stays I’ve never had an issue. The neighborhood is great too. Lots of good restaurants, bars and cafes. Highly recommend this place.

I had a semi-business/pleasure trip planned for San Francisco. Golden Gate Hotel was the best location for both. The light rail (BART) has direct connections from San Francisco Airport. It dropped me and my wheeled suitcase at Powell and Market and a slow walk up hill had me arriving at the hotel in good time.For the solo or group traveler there are several nearby restaurants to either get food to go or to sit and eat. The Asian Museum was only a 10-15 minute walk. Grace Cathedral is just 3 blocks away. (Very steep but doable if you're patient enough to walk slowly.) In addition to religious services there are concerts on Sundays.China town is several short blocks down hill.A continental breakfast of tea and coffee along with a basket of baked goods and OJ are served each morning. Tea and cookies are served at 4 PM. I have been here before and always have an opportunity to chat with fellow travelers from all over the world.

The Golden Gate Hotel was just like a perfect English B&B in both service and decor. From 'tea and cookies in the parlour' at 4pm to the ancient lift and proper tea in a pot with huge croissants and muffins for breakfast you cannot fault it. Comfy bed, very clean, great service and Pip the cat who entertained us with his antics of cajoling - and often bullying - staff to give him treats. A great 3 night stay. We had a room with a shower, sink and a shared toilet which we coped with very well. Perfect location for walking out to Union Square, China town, The Cable Car Museum and Fisherman's Wharf - all of which we did. Nice restaurants nearby too - try Bouche and Cafe de la Press. We would stay here again anytime.

We spend four nights here over a long weekend in Sa n Francisco. The staff are so friendly as is the house cat! Breakfast is served every morning downstairs - croissants, jam, muffins and coffee. Afternoon tea and cookies are also served every day as well. The rooms are very comfy and full of charm. The hotel is in a great location close to Union Square and Powel Street BART station which is an easy 30 min journey from the airport. Would definitely recommend staying here.

I searched for weeks trying to find a hotel in San Fran that had a good location but did not break the bank; I stumbled upon Golden Gate Hotel. I read lots of reviews, and I went for it. This charming little hotel is located near Chinatown in a great location for walking for those riding public transportation. We also had a rental car with us, even though we didn't use it around the city, and the hotel offers a discount at the parking garage directly across the street for $30/day, which is a great find in the city if you must park. The hotel has an vintage feel with the antique elevator and furnishings, but our room was very clean. It was actually the best bed I slept in on our 10 day trip around California. The breakfast was good in the morning - croissants, coffee, etc. We never took advantage of the afternoon tea, but we were told it was available. All the staff was accommodating and pleasant as well. I would definitely stay here again if in San Francisco.

I recently stayed here for 5 nights.If you want to have a place to complement your San Francisco experience - it’s here. The service is top notch. From the moment I arrived, I was made to feel welcome. I love this place. The cookies, the cat, the fireplace, chocolates, I’ll let you discover the rest. Honestly you can’t go wrong here. Convenient parking, owners and staff who really care, brilliantly furnished and a superb location. Definitely value for money. I’m definitely coming back.

I was traveling with my wife. We both love this boutique hotel. First of all is 'very San Francisco', you can feel the atmosphere of this lovely city there. It is small but very nice and comfortable, clean and calm. But first of all the owners are nice, friendly, elegant and very very polite and helpful with extremely good manners people. I recommend this place for everyone searching for something different.

Retro and romantic place. Superior hospitality. French style breakfast with best coffee & tea. A comparatively good price. 5 min walkway from Union square and 25 min from Pier39 and Port. To sum it up: SFOs best! Have stayed there multiple times in the last 30 years.

My girlfriend and I stayed a couple nights here last week. The rooms were squeaky clean, comfortable and nostalgic. The staff was AMAZING! My girlfriend got food poisoning and they did everything in their power to accommodate and make her feel as comfortable as possible! We will not forget your kindness and will be back! Oh, and Pip the Cat was the perfect ambassador! He will say "hello" every time you enter the lobby, no joke. Ask where his treats are and he will love you. What a character he was.

Stayed in this charming hotel for four nights (with a break at a Yosemite in the middle). While the rooms are on the small side the hotel has a lovely homely feel. The staff were always friendly and helpful.The communal breakfast was a nice chance to catch up with other visitors and trade SF tips, and we enjoyed breaking up our day with the tea and cookies on offer in afternoon.The hotel is in a great location - within walking distance to many sites and with easy access to public transportation.San Francisco accommodation is notoriously expensive but for the area we found this place to be great value. Would definitely recommend!

My 3 nights in the wonderful and fist B & B was wonderful. The room (although a shared bathroom, it was always clean) is comfortable and well appointed, the breakfast yummy and filing and the staff were all great! Location was safe and central. I definitely recommend!

The Golden Gate Hotel it's a small Hotel with minimalist features, an almost non-existent lobby, and a very small dining area that seats about 12 people comfortably. That being said , it reminds me of some of the smaller hotels I've stayed in places like Paris and the outskirts of Rome. If you are looking for a Westin or a Hilton this is not the place. If you're looking for a place with some character and charm at a reasonable price then this is the place.On the inside it's clearly a B&B Style Hotel comma the rooms are a little bit dated but not didn't you or dirty .. more like something you would find in the berkshires of Massachusetts then the tourist district of San Francisco .. especially the cat that has free roam of the lobby area and stairs and hallways and the owners quartersYou should make sure to review their website carefully, there are some rooms with shared bathrooms so if that's not your thing make sure to read the details of your reservation. The breakfast is minimal but adequate to get your day started and the people are so pleasant. If you want a full breakfast there are plenty of places nearby at very reasonable prices. I know this might not sound like the greatest review but finding a location like this in San Francisco is really quite a find if you're open to a place that feels like you're staying at your grandparents house comma I know I will be back again.

After an extremely long flight, I was greeted by Halim who was very helpful and welcoming. He immediately offered me warm croissants and fresh orange juice as it was already quite late at night to go out for a meal. I stayed for five nights on vacation. The rear room at the back was spotless and perfect. It was very quiet and looked onto a neighboring garden. The bed was very comfortable and I slept so well. Loved this place. It is warm and cozy. The owners and the entire team of staff will do anything to make your stay super comfortable. The fresh croissants and coffee fior breakfast are lovely. The hotel is very clean and it really feels at home. Location is perfect and walking distance to all the sights. I had an excellent stay and will be back. Awesome. Thank you !!

This cozy place is located within walking distance from many San Francisco attractions. The rooms are very comfortable and has everything you need, maybe not the most modern things but this is not that kind of hotel, it feels a little like staying at your grand mothers house – in a very good way! Everything is very clean and well maintained. The staff is friendly and helpful and the house cat is adorable. You get a nice breakfast with fresh croissants and good coffee. Don’t forget to visit the excellent beer bar Hopwater Distribution next door.

A very warm welcoming, good breakfast (they got croissants), nice cat. The bedrooms are really charming and fancy. The fact that the hotel is in downtown SF makes it convenient. Excellent value for money. The staff is super nice (some of them speak french). I highly recommend this hotel.
#NAME?

I' am a San Franciscan who was thoroughly impressed with this quaint hotel. This hotel and the staff put corporate hotels to shame. It is in a great location; especially for tourists. The atmosphere was warm and welcoming. The staff went above and beyond to assist with my every need. The staff is polite and soft-spoken. You will be doing yourself a discredit if you choose not to stay there.I would give the hotel ten stars if I could!!

Spencer and the entire staff could not be friendlier or more welcoming. If they can accommodate a request, they'll do it immediately. Rooms are spotless. Breakfast is good, especially the almond croissants and the muffins. Coffee is excellent. Location convenient to downtown, Chinatown, North Beach and BART to/from the airport. And having Pip around to greet you when you walk in (or not, depending on his mood, of course) is an added bonus.

We didn't plan our dates correctly while in SF so we found this place for one night. We couldn't have been happier.. We loved, loved ,loved, the charm of this place. I wish we could have stayed longer. We had an early flight and didn't get to stay for breakfast which I truly regret. The woman who owns this place is an elderly German woman who I have heard puts out a lovely breakfast. The room was very clean with charm that i wish you could fist everywhere but you just can't. It has a very old fashioned elevator that I have had the opportunity to ride one other time in my life. A claw foot bathtub which I hadn't used since I was a child. It was not convienent to the wharf but a cab ride was only like $7.00which was cheaper than other options. The beds were very comfortable.

Historic beautiful hotel with very good service, small pricy rooms (probably normal for SF center) and typical French small breakfast Pro's- location of hotel is really close to center with union square and China town around the corner - staff is super friendly and welcoming and give lots of tips - super nice setting with antique elevator, many antique decorations, etc - many amenities in your room to make your stay pleasant - they have a high chair for infants for breakfast (and a cat for his entertainment)Con's- quite noisy in hotel as it is old and noise travels easily through walls. - Makes it challenging when you are travelling with a baby, you don't want the baby to cry in your room as you are afraid the whole floor will wake up - quite pricy for a small room with shared bathroom - breakfast was mainly coffee with croissants so limited if you are used to having a breakfast with at least some yogurt and granola or regular bread rolls

This was my 2nd stay at this small hotel. The last time was 17-years ago - nothing change, even better! Hotel cat, Pip, greeted us when we checked in, came to the room by the classic elevator. The room is not very large, but very quiet and clean. You can feel like staying at friend's home. Breakfast is served in the salon at the ground floor. Croissant, muffin table rolls, orange juice and coffee or tea. To take the cable car, you don't need to wait in queue at Market street station. The cable car stop is just 2-3 min walk from the hotel.
